author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Amber manipulates Sir Frederick into marrying her mother-in-law, the Dowager Baroness, by falsely claiming that she is wealthy and has suitors.

title: Forever Amber
author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Amber confronts Gerald about his affair with Mrs. Polly Stark and proposes a deal to salvage their marriage.
recaptext: Amber, a young woman in London, faces a series of unfortunate events and ends up in prison. She finds protection with a highwayman named Black Jack Mallard but their relationship becomes strained. She meets Theophilus Bidulph and becomes a popular actress, encountering various romantic interests along the way. As the plague spreads, Amber faces worsening conditions and tries to protect her sick husband Bruce. Eventually, they recover from the plague and plan to escape the city, but Amber becomes doubtful about Bruce's intentions. She attends a dinner, accepts a proposal from the Earl of Radclyffe, and becomes the Countess of Radclyffe. However, she soon feels bored and resentful, and her infatuation with Charles leads to a plan to kill Radclyffe. Amber engages in flirtations, confronts Radclyffe, and escapes during a fire. She puts on mourning but feels haunted by Radclyffe's presence. Amber befriends Frances Stewart and reveals she is pregnant with the King's child. Charles suggests she marry a baron, causing tension. Frances reveals her affair, Barbara seeks help in determining the father of her child, and Charles plans to gather evidence against Buckingham. Amber, now married to Gerald Stanhope, attends a ball to assert her social status. Lady Stanhope receives a letter informing her that her son, Gerald, has married the former Countess of Radclyffe but they are not living together. Concerned, Lady Stanhope meets her new daughter-in-law, Amber, and disapproves of their living arrangement. Lady Stanhope offers Amber a place to stay in London, and Amber reluctantly accepts. As Amber navigates her pregnancy and her strained relationship with Gerald, she forms a connection with Bruce, who is married to another woman. When the Dutch invade London, Bruce prepares to leave to fight, while Amber refuses to leave in case she hears from him. Eventually, Amber decides to go to America with Bruce and their son, bidding an emotional farewell. The Duke of Buckingham sends a young boy to the Tower to inform the sentry that he is waiting at the Sun Tavern to be arrested. He enjoys his dinner while a crowd gathers outside, cheering for him. Barbara, the Countess, encounters a beggar who gives her a folded paper and warns her about the Duke of Buckingham's impending downfall. Lady Stanhope slaps a young boy and feels frustrated in the council-room as she awaits the arrival of the councillors for Buckingham's trial. Buckingham defends himself against accusations of treason and reveals that his sister commissioned the horoscope, causing astonishment among the council members. Harry Killigrew insults the Duke of Buckingham's mistress, leading to a heated argument that escalates into a physical altercation in the theater, with Buckingham ultimately overpowering and humiliating Killigrew in front of a jeering crowd. Amber reflects on her newfound wealth and status as the Countess of Radclyffe, while dealing with the return of her husband Gerald and her disapproving mother-in-law Lucilla, who accuses her of carrying the King's child. Amber gives Lady Stanhope a furious ultimatum and collapses into a chair, overwhelmed by the dark morbidity of her pregnancy. Dr. Fraser delivers Amber's long, thin baby, and Charles visits the newborn and remarks on the baby's resemblance to himself. Gerald, dressed as a fop, awkwardly meets the baby and leaves abruptly to attend the play. Amber plans to find a husband for her troublesome mother-in-law, Lucilla, who is attracted to a young fop named Sir Frederick Fothergill.

title: Forever Amber
author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Amber confronts Gerald about his relationship with Mrs. Stark and offers him a deal to keep her happy, while Gerald is unsure and asks Amber not to tell his mother.

title: Forever Amber
author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Gerald agrees to Amber's deal and tensions rise as Amber becomes more involved with Charles and Lucilla becomes suspicious.

title: Forever Amber
author: Kathleen Winsor
text: James, the Duke of York, expresses his concerns to King Charles about the Chancellor, Clarendon, and his wife's fear that the King intends to dismiss him. Charles assures James that he will deal with the Chancellor as kindly as he can, but believes that Clarendon's usefulness has come to an end.

title: Forever Amber
author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Charles informs Clarendon that there is a demand for new men in the government and suggests that he anticipates their wishes by resigning. Clarendon is taken aback by the news and questions if the decision is influenced by Barbara, but Charles denies it and stands firm in his decision.

text: Charles' dismissal of Clarendon causes fear and uncertainty among the courtiers, while Barbara remains confident in her ability to maintain her position at court.

title: Forever Amber
author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Barbara leaves for a few weeks, hoping Charles will miss her and ask her to return, while settling into a messy lodging in Maypole Alley. Charles ponders their relationship and the possibility of rekindling his love for her.

title: Forever Amber
author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Nelly, a young actress, impresses Charles Hart and John Lacy with her dancing skills, but becomes frustrated by the lack of attention she receives due to the King's new mistress. Mary Knight invites Nelly to meet King Charles II, causing her to feel overwhelmed and unsure about going.

title: Forever Amber
author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Nelly gathers her courage and enters the palace to meet King Charles II. She is nervous and self-conscious about her appearance, but Mary encourages her to go. Nelly knocks on the door, ready to face the King.

title: Forever Amber
author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Nelly Gwynne arrives at a handsomely furnished room and meets William Chiffinch, the King's Page of the Backstairs, who gives her a bottle of perfume and guides her to the King's presence.

title: Forever Amber
author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Nelly Gwynne enters the King's presence and discusses her yearly allowance, but the King laughs at her request for five hundred pounds. Chiffinch comforts her, assuring her that she will receive more from the King in the future.

title: Forever Amber
author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Nelly visits Moll Davis, who has been making fun of her, and brings her a box of homemade candy as a peace offering.

title: Forever Amber
author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Nelly confronts Moll about the rumors and shows her generosity by bringing her candy. However, Moll continues to boast about her gifts from the King, causing Nelly to feel hurt and jealous.

As the plague spreads, Amber faces worsening conditions and tries to protect her sick husband Bruce. Eventually, they recover from the plague and plan to escape the city, but Amber becomes doubtful about Bruce's intentions. However, she soon feels bored and resentful, and her infatuation with Charles leads to a plan to kill Radclyffe. Amber engages in flirtations, confronts Radclyffe, and escapes during a fire. She puts on mourning but feels haunted by Radclyffe's presence. Amber befriends Frances Stewart and reveals she is pregnant with the King's child. Charles suggests she marry a baron, causing tension. Frances reveals her affair, Barbara seeks help in determining the father of her child, and Charles plans to gather evidence against Buckingham. Concerned, Lady Stanhope meets her new daughter-in-law, Amber, and disapproves of their living arrangement. Lady Stanhope offers Amber a place to stay in London, and Amber reluctantly accepts. As Amber navigates her pregnancy and her strained relationship with Gerald, she forms a connection with Bruce, who is married to another woman. When the Dutch invade London, Bruce prepares to leave to fight, while Amber refuses to leave in case she hears from him. Eventually, Amber decides to go to America with Bruce and their son, bidding an emotional farewell. Nelly Gwynne arrives at a handsomely furnished room and meets William Chiffinch, the King's Page of the Backstairs, who gives her a bottle of perfume and guides her to the King's presence.

author: Kathleen Winsor

author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Nelly captivates the King's attention and they develop a closer relationship, leading to more secret meetings and shared moments of amusement. However, their connection becomes a source of jealousy and tension among the courtiers, ultimately leading to a confrontation between Nelly and Moll.

author: Kathleen Winsor

title: Forever Amber
author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Lady Stanhope disapproves of Amber's living arrangement with her son Gerald and offers her a place to stay in London. Amber reluctantly accepts and becomes fully immersed in Court life, attending suppers, plays, and balls, spending money extravagantly, and engaging in various money-making ventures, enjoying her newfound status and influence.

text: Amber continues to feel unhappy despite her extravagant lifestyle and busy social life, as her longing for Bruce Carlton persists and becomes overwhelming.

title: Forever Amber
author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Amber expresses her longing for Bruce and questions Almsbury about any news from him, but Almsbury dismisses her hopes and reveals that Bruce loves Corinna. Despite this, Amber insists that Bruce loves her too and confesses her deep love for him.

title: Forever Amber
author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Amber becomes determined to win back Bruce's love and prove that she is the one he truly desires. She devises a plan to make Bruce realize his true feelings for her and sets out to execute it with unwavering determination.

Despite this, Amber insists that Bruce loves her too and confesses her deep love for him. Amber plans her day, goes driving in Hyde Park, and contemplates the changing dynamics at Court, including the return of Frances Stewart and the rise of new mistresses. The Duke of Buckingham visits Amber and shows her a satirical petition mocking Lady Castlemaine, causing them both to laugh and share a moment of amusement. title: Forever Amber
author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Charles supports Frances through her recovery from smallpox, seeking ways to restore her beauty and offering her comfort and support. Their bond grows stronger as they navigate this difficult time together.
recaptext: Amber, a young woman in London, faces a series of unfortunate events and ends up in prison. She finds protection with a highwayman named Black Jack Mallard but their relationship becomes strained. As the plague spreads, Amber faces worsening conditions and tries to protect her sick husband Bruce. Eventually, they recover from the plague and plan to escape the city, but Amber becomes doubtful about Bruce's intentions. She attends a dinner, accepts a proposal from the Earl of Radclyffe, and becomes the Countess of Radclyffe. However, she soon feels bored and resentful, and her infatuation with Charles leads to a plan to kill Radclyffe. Amber engages in flirtations, confronts Radclyffe, and escapes during a fire. She puts on mourning but feels haunted by Radclyffe's presence. Amber befriends Frances Stewart and reveals she is pregnant with the King's child. Charles suggests she marry a baron, causing tension. Frances reveals her affair, Barbara seeks help in determining the father of her child, and Charles plans to gather evidence against Buckingham. Amber, now married to Gerald Stanhope, attends a ball to assert her social status. Lady Stanhope receives a letter informing her that her son, Gerald, has married the former Countess of Radclyffe but they are not living together. Concerned, Lady Stanhope meets her new daughter-in-law, Amber, and disapproves of their living arrangement. Lady Stanhope offers Amber a place to stay in London, and Amber reluctantly accepts. As Amber navigates her pregnancy and her strained relationship with Gerald, she forms a connection with Bruce, who is married to another woman. When the Dutch invade London, Bruce prepares to leave to fight, while Amber refuses to leave in case she hears from him. Eventually, Amber decides to go to America with Bruce and their son, bidding an emotional farewell. The Duke of Buckingham, facing impending downfall, defends himself against accusations of treason and surprises the council members with a revelation about his sister. Amber, now the Countess of Radclyffe, deals with her disapproving mother-in-law and the return of her husband, while also manipulating a marriage for her mother-in-law. Charles, the King, dismisses the Chancellor and confronts his failing marriage with Barbara. Nelly, a young actress, becomes frustrated by the King's new mistress but is invited to meet Charles II. Nelly Gwynne arrives at a handsomely furnished room and meets William Chiffinch, the King's Page of the Backstairs, who gives her a bottle of perfume and guides her to the King's presence. Nelly visits Moll Davis, who has been making fun of her, and brings her a box of homemade candy as a peace offering. Nelly goes to the Duke's Theatre with John Villiers and sees the King and his brother in the adjoining box, causing her to feel nervous and embarrassed. She eventually engages in a playful conversation with the King and exchanges gestures with Moll Davis during her performance. Nelly, Charles, and James enjoy a lavish supper at the Rose Tavern, but when it's time to pay the bill, they realize they have no money. Nelly finds it amusing, but Villiers reluctantly pays the bill. Amber goes through Radclyffe's possessions, destroys his writings, and keeps some of his belongings for herself, reveling in her triumph over him. Amber expresses her longing for Bruce and questions Almsbury about any news from him, but Almsbury dismisses her hopes and reveals that Bruce loves Corinna. Despite this, Amber insists that Bruce loves her too and confesses her deep love for him. The Duke of Buckingham visits Amber and shows her a satirical petition mocking Lady Castlemaine, causing them both to laugh and share a moment of amusement. Amber discusses the downfall of Barbara Palmer, the King's former mistress, with the Duke of Buckingham, who reveals that he played a role in her downfall by convincing the King that her love letters were burned. Amber and the Duke of Buckingham discuss their potential alliance and shared interests, while Frances Stewart grows bored and unhappy in her marriage and longs for the attention of King Charles.

title: Forever Amber
author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Frances, who has recovered from smallpox but feels ugly and devastated, is comforted by Charles, who reassures her that she will regain her beauty and tries to distract her from her own tragedy.

author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Frances seeks solace in Charles' affection and support after recovering from smallpox, while Charles becomes determined to make her his own and devises a plan to win her over.

author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Buckingham tricks Father Scroope into coming to his house under false pretenses, reveals his true identity, and proposes a plan to convince Catherine of Braganza to retire to a nunnery so that King Charles can marry again and have an heir.

author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Amber overhears Father Scroope selling Buckingham's plot against the Queen and expresses her horror and anger. Father Scroope leaves quickly, and Amber and Nan encounter a man who was caught snooping outside. Amber interrogates him and orders Big John to whip him until he confesses.

author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Amber demands the man to reveal why he was snooping and who sent him. After being whipped, the man finally confesses, providing information that implicates someone close to Amber. Amber confronts this person and gathers evidence to expose their betrayal.

title: Forever Amber
author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Amber tries to maintain favor with the King and smooth things over with Buckingham, while Buckingham plots to ruin her and seeks revenge for her interference.
recaptext: Amber, a young woman in London, faces a series of unfortunate events and ends up in prison. She finds protection with a highwayman named Black Jack Mallard but their relationship becomes strained. She meets Theophilus Bidulph and becomes a popular actress, encountering various romantic interests along the way. As the plague spreads, Amber faces worsening conditions and tries to protect her sick husband Bruce. Eventually, they recover from the plague and plan to escape the city, but Amber becomes doubtful about Bruce's intentions. She attends a dinner, accepts a proposal from the Earl of Radclyffe, and becomes the Countess of Radclyffe. However, she soon feels bored and resentful, and her infatuation with Charles leads to a plan to kill Radclyffe. Amber engages in flirtations, confronts Radclyffe, and escapes during a fire. She puts on mourning but feels haunted by Radclyffe's presence. Amber befriends Frances Stewart and reveals she is pregnant with the King's child. Charles suggests she marry a baron, causing tension. Frances reveals her affair, Barbara seeks help in determining the father of her child, and Charles plans to gather evidence against Buckingham. Amber, now married to Gerald Stanhope, attends a ball to assert her social status. Lady Stanhope receives a letter informing her that her son, Gerald, has married the former Countess of Radclyffe but they are not living together. Concerned, Lady Stanhope meets her new daughter-in-law, Amber, and disapproves of their living arrangement. Lady Stanhope offers Amber a place to stay in London, and Amber reluctantly accepts. As Amber navigates her pregnancy and her strained relationship with Gerald, she forms a connection with Bruce, who is married to another woman. When the Dutch invade London, Bruce prepares to leave to fight, while Amber refuses to leave in case she hears from him. Eventually, Amber decides to go to America with Bruce and their son, bidding an emotional farewell. The Duke of Buckingham, facing impending downfall, defends himself against accusations of treason and surprises the council members with a revelation about his sister. Amber, now the Countess of Radclyffe, deals with her disapproving mother-in-law and the return of her husband, while also manipulating a marriage for her mother-in-law. Charles, the King, dismisses the Chancellor and confronts his failing marriage with Barbara. Nelly, a young actress, becomes frustrated by the King's new mistress but is invited to meet Charles II. Nelly Gwynne, a young woman, is introduced to the King by William Chiffinch. She tries to make amends with Moll Davis and later attends a play with John Villiers, where she catches the attention of the King. Nelly, Charles, and James have a meal but can't pay the bill, so Villiers covers it. Amber triumphs over Radclyffe and expresses her love for Bruce, despite learning he loves someone else. She contemplates life at Court and shares a laugh with the Duke of Buckingham. Frances Stewart falls ill, and Charles visits her, feeling pity for her appearance. Amber becomes emotional and runs away, while someone heads towards Somerset House. Buckingham proposes a plan to convince Catherine of Braganza to retire to a nunnery so that Charles can remarry. Amber overhears Father Scroope selling Buckingham's plot against the Queen and expresses her horror and anger. Father Scroope leaves quickly, and Amber and Nan encounter a man who was caught snooping outside. Amber interrogates him and orders Big John to whip him until he confesses. Amber interrogates a man who was caught snooping outside and orders Big John to whip him until he confesses. She then talks with the Queen and gains her goodwill, discussing a plan to get rid of Catherine's enemies.

title: Forever Amber
author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Baron Arlington pays a secret visit to Amber, discussing Buckingham's jealousy and offering to help her secure a dukedom.

title: Forever Amber
author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Amber accepts Baron Arlington's offer and they form an alliance to further her ambitions. They devise a plan to gain the favor of the King and secure the dukedom for Amber's son.

title: Forever Amber
author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Amber, now the Countess of Radclyffe, discusses a plan with Baron Arlington to gather information about Buckingham's meetings with Commonwealth men in order to report it back to Arlington and gain his support.

title: Forever Amber
author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Amber constructs an extravagant house in St. James's Square, believing she will soon be granted a duchy. As weeks pass and she remains only a countess, Amber becomes determined to find a way to get what she wants and continues to use her influence and manipulate others to achieve her goals.

title: Forever Amber
author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Amber revels in her scandalous reputation and popularity, attending social events, engaging in intrigues, and maintaining her extravagant lifestyle. However, as rumors of a pending French-English alliance and York's Catholicism spread, the political climate becomes more tense, and Amber finds herself caught up in the intrigue and uncertainty of the royal court.

title: Forever Amber
author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Amber visits Ravenspur House with Captain Wynne and discusses the progress of the construction. She observes the luxurious decorations and furniture planned for the house, and spends time with her children, Susanna and Charles Stanhope.

title: Forever Amber
author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Amber receives news that the guests she has been waiting for have arrived, leaving her shocked and unsettled. Almsbury stands close to her, holding her arm for support.

author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Amber learns that Lord Carlton, her former lover, is married to a beautiful woman named Corinna, which causes her great distress. She invites Lord Carlton and his wife to a supper, but they are unable to attend due to fatigue from their recent voyage.

author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Amber works with Madame Rouvière to create a stunning and provocative gown that will outshine Lady Carlton at the upcoming event.

title: Forever Amber
author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Amber expresses her love for Bruce and her willingness to leave everything behind for him, but he dismisses her feelings and emphasizes her position and wealth as unimportant. Amber becomes jealous and upset when Bruce leaves to be with his wife.

title: Forever Amber
author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Amber becomes determined to prove her worth and win back Bruce's affection, using her power and influence to manipulate situations in her favor. She sets out to create scandal and maintain her reputation, all in an effort to regain Bruce's attention and love.

As Amber navigates her pregnancy and her strained relationship with Gerald, she forms a connection with Bruce, who is married to another woman. When the Dutch invade London, Bruce prepares to leave to fight, while Amber refuses to leave in case she hears from him. Eventually, Amber decides to go to America with Bruce and their son, bidding an emotional farewell. The Duke of Buckingham, facing impending downfall, defends himself against accusations of treason and surprises the council members with a revelation about his sister. Amber, now the Countess of Radclyffe, deals with her disapproving mother-in-law and the return of her husband, while also manipulating a marriage for her mother-in-law. Charles, the King, dismisses the Chancellor and confronts his failing marriage with Barbara. Nelly, a young actress, becomes frustrated by the King's new mistress but is invited to meet Charles II. Nelly Gwynne, a young woman, is introduced to the King by William Chiffinch. She tries to make amends with Moll Davis and later attends a play with John Villiers, where she catches the attention of the King. Nelly, Charles, and James have a meal but can't pay the bill, so Villiers covers it. Amber triumphs over Radclyffe and expresses her love for Bruce, despite learning he loves someone else. She contemplates life at Court and shares a laugh with the Duke of Buckingham. Frances Stewart falls ill, and Charles visits her, feeling pity for her appearance. Amber becomes emotional and runs away, while someone heads towards Somerset House. Buckingham proposes a plan to convince Catherine of Braganza to retire to a nunnery so that Charles can remarry. Amber, a woman of influence, discovers a plot against the Queen and gains her favor. She forms alliances with powerful figures, including Baron Arlington, to secure her own position. Amber navigates the social scene, creating scandal and maintaining her reputation. However, her former lover's marriage causes her distress, and she becomes overwhelmed by the attention and jealousy at a grand party. Despite her emotional struggles, Amber finds solace in her daughter and the loyalty of those close to her.

author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Amber continues her affair with Lord Carlton, growing more confident in their relationship despite the risk of being discovered by Corinna. However, their secret meetings are eventually exposed when the Countess of Southesk and Jane Middleton encounter Bruce leaving Amber's chamber, leading to potential scandal and gossip at the Court.

Bruce prepares to leave to fight, while Amber refuses to leave in case she hears from him. Eventually, Amber decides to go to America with Bruce and their son, bidding an emotional farewell. Meanwhile, the Duke of Buckingham defends himself against accusations of treason and surprises the council members with a revelation about his sister. Amber, now the Countess of Radclyffe, deals with her disapproving mother-in-law and the return of her husband, while also manipulating a marriage for her mother-in-law. Charles confronts his failing marriage with Barbara, and Nelly Gwynne, a young actress, catches the attention of the King. Amber triumphs over Radclyffe and expresses her love for Bruce, despite learning he loves someone else. She navigates the social scene, creates scandal, and maintains her reputation. Despite her emotional struggles, Amber finds solace in her daughter and the loyalty of those close to her. Amber expresses her love for Bruce and her willingness to leave everything behind for him, but he dismisses her feelings and emphasizes her position and wealth as unimportant. Amber becomes jealous and upset when Bruce leaves to be with his wife. Amber is reunited with her son Bruce and they spend time together, reminiscing about their lives in America and England, while Amber contemplates her feelings for Lord Carlton and the potential consequences of their affair. Amber is taking a bath in her bedroom while tradespeople are present, and she engages in a conversation with her guests about her new eunuch, Herman, and Lord Carlton. Amber meets Corinna, the wife of Lord Carlton, and feels resentful and jealous as she observes Corinna's appearance and happiness. Amber overhears a conversation between Corinna and Lady Southesk about Lord Carlton being Barbara Palmer's newest conquest, causing Amber to become furious and confront Bruce about his affair with Barbara. Corinna becomes increasingly jealous and resentful of the Duchess of Ravenspur's interactions with her husband Bruce, but she tries to convince herself that it's just idle gossip and remains determined to maintain her faith in their marriage. Corinna expresses her jealousy and resentment towards the Duchess of Ravenspur, but her fears are alleviated when Bruce reassures her of his love and their past memories together. Corinna goes to the New Exchange with her waiting-woman and mistakenly believes she sees her husband, Lord Carlton, talking to the Duchess of Ravenspur, causing her to feel confused and ashamed. Corinna receives a visit from Lady Castlemaine, who tries to undermine her marriage by showing her a scandalous poem about the Duchess of Ravenspur and Lord Carlton. Corinna confronts Bruce about his affair with the Duchess of Ravenspur and learns that the Duchess is the mother of their son. Corinna expresses her feelings of not belonging to the court and admits her concern about her husband's love for someone else, while Bruce reassures her and apologizes for hurting her. Amber arrives at a bookstore to meet Bruce, who has been avoiding her, and anxiously waits for him to notice her presence. Amber confronts Bruce about his affair with Corinna and pleads with him to continue their relationship, but Bruce insists that they will never see each other again. Amber shows Bruce the grandeur of Ravenspur House, boasting about its luxurious features and her wealth, while Bruce expresses concern about her financial security and aging. Music, laughter, and revelry fill the house as guests dance, gamble, and enjoy entertainment. Amber orchestrates a scandalous prank on Barbara Palmer, causing tension, but the party is deemed a success.

title: Forever Amber
author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Amber and Bruce have a heated argument about their relationship, with Amber expressing her frustration and anger towards Bruce's secrecy and lack of commitment. Bruce decides to leave, and Amber is left devastated and alone.

title: Forever Amber
author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Amber spends six days without seeing Bruce, feeling desperate and hoping for him to return. However, Bruce does not come back, leaving Amber to grapple with her emotions and uncertainty about their future together.

She finds protection with a highwayman named Black Jack Mallard but their relationship becomes strained. She meets Theophilus Bidulph and becomes a popular actress, encountering various romantic interests along the way. As the plague spreads, Amber faces worsening conditions and tries to protect her sick husband Bruce. Eventually, they recover from the plague and plan to escape the city, but Amber becomes doubtful about Bruce's intentions. She attends a dinner, accepts a proposal from the Earl of Radclyffe, and becomes the Countess of Radclyffe. However, she soon feels bored and resentful, and her infatuation with Charles leads to a plan to kill Radclyffe. Amber engages in flirtations, confronts Radclyffe, and escapes during a fire. She befriends Frances Stewart and reveals she is pregnant with the King's child. Charles suggests she marry a baron, causing tension. Frances reveals her affair, Barbara seeks help in determining the father of her child, and Charles plans to gather evidence against Buckingham. Despite her emotional struggles, Amber finds solace in her daughter and the loyalty of those close to her. Amber, a wealthy woman, confesses her love for Bruce, but he rejects her and goes back to his wife. Amber spends time with her son Bruce, reflecting on their lives and her feelings for Lord Carlton. Amber becomes jealous when she sees Bruce with his wife and confronts him about his affair with Barbara. Meanwhile, Corinna, Bruce's wife, struggles with jealousy and confronts him about his infidelity. Eventually, Bruce and Amber reconcile and find happiness together.

author: Kathleen Winsor

author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Amber's intense search for the person she is looking for continues, leading her to confront Corinna and confront her feelings of hatred. She may also make a decision or take action based on her emotions.

text: Amber's attempt to humiliate Corinna backfires as Corinna remains composed. Frustrated, Amber storms out, determined to find another way to win Bruce back.

author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Amber lies senseless on the floor after being attacked by Bruce, and then spends several days in her bedroom, feeling desolate and indifferent to everything around her. Amber receives a visit from Charles, who tries to engage her in his latest plot, but she remains indifferent. However, she starts to regain her energy and devises a plan to deceive Buckingham, outwit Baron Arlington, and make a large sum of money with little risk.

author: Kathleen Winsor

author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Amber and Lord Arlington negotiate their agreement, but their mutual dislike becomes evident. Amber successfully deceives Buckingham by giving him a harmless sleeping-potion instead of poison, leading to a confrontation between them.

author: Kathleen Winsor

title: Forever Amber
author: Kathleen Winsor
text: Amber boards her coach and heads to the wharf to meet Nan and the children, ready to embark on her journey to Virginia. She encounters Lord Arlington and the Duke of Buckingham, who seem to know something about her plans, but she dismisses their presence and focuses on her excitement to leave England behind.
recaptext: Amber, a young woman in London, faces a series of unfortunate events and ends up in prison. She finds protection with a highwayman named Black Jack Mallard but their relationship becomes strained. She meets Theophilus Bidulph and becomes a popular actress, encountering various romantic interests along the way. As the plague spreads, Amber faces worsening conditions and tries to protect her sick husband Bruce. Eventually, they recover from the plague and plan to escape the city, but Amber becomes doubtful about Bruce's intentions. She attends a dinner, accepts a proposal from the Earl of Radclyffe, and becomes the Countess of Radclyffe. However, she soon feels bored and resentful, and her infatuation with Charles leads to a plan to kill Radclyffe. Amber engages in flirtations, confronts Radclyffe, and escapes during a fire. She befriends Frances Stewart and reveals she is pregnant with the King's child. Charles suggests she marry a baron, causing tension. Frances reveals her affair, Barbara seeks help in determining the father of her child, and Charles plans to gather evidence against Buckingham. Amber, now married to Gerald Stanhope, attends a ball to assert her social status. Lady Stanhope disapproves of their living arrangement and offers Amber a place to stay in London, which she reluctantly accepts. As Amber navigates her strained relationship with Gerald and forms a connection with Bruce, who is married to another woman, the Dutch invade London. Bruce prepares to leave to fight, while Amber refuses to leave in case she hears from him. Eventually, Amber decides to go to America with Bruce and their son, bidding an emotional farewell. Meanwhile, the Duke of Buckingham defends himself against accusations of treason and surprises the council members with a revelation about his sister. Amber, now the Countess of Radclyffe, deals with her disapproving mother-in-law and the return of her husband, while also manipulating a marriage for her mother-in-law. Charles confronts his failing marriage with Barbara, and Nelly Gwynne, a young actress, catches the attention of the King. Amber triumphs over Radclyffe and expresses her love for Bruce, despite learning he loves someone else. She navigates the social scene, creates scandal, and maintains her reputation. Despite her emotional struggles, Amber finds solace in her daughter and the loyalty of those close to her. Amber, a wealthy woman, confesses her love for Bruce, but he rejects her and goes back to his wife. Amber spends time with her son Bruce, reflecting on their lives and her feelings for Lord Carlton. Amber becomes jealous when she sees Bruce with his wife and confronts him about his affair with Barbara. Meanwhile, Corinna, Bruce's wife, struggles with jealousy and confronts him about his infidelity. Eventually, Bruce and Amber reconcile and find happiness together. Amber and Bruce have a heated argument about their relationship, with Amber expressing her frustration and anger towards Bruce's secrecy and lack of commitment. Bruce decides to leave, and Amber is left devastated and alone. Amber attends a raffle at the India House and becomes consumed with searching for someone, while feeling a surge of hatred towards Corinna. Amber engages in a bidding war with Corinna over a piece of cloth at an auction, determined to win at any cost, but is ultimately outbid by Lord Carlton. Amber sends a challenge to Bruce, disguised as her husband, in an attempt to make him see her again. Amber pleads desperately with Bruce to see him again, but he remains firm and walks away, leaving her devastated. Charles reunites with his sister Minette on a French sailing vessel, and they are overjoyed to see each other again after ten years apart. They are surrounded by a crowd of men and women, including Louise de Kerouaille, who is intrigued by Charles. Charles and Minette discuss the signing of a treaty, with Charles revealing his amusement and future plans for England, while Minette expresses concern about his declaration of Catholicism. Charles and Minette have an intimate conversation about their love for each other and their concerns about Philippe's behavior, leading Charles to express his anger and determination to protect Minette. Amber becomes increasingly anxious and impatient to see Lord Carlton again, and decides to visit Lady Carlton in hopes of finding him. Amber confronts Corinna about Bruce's infidelity, boasting about their secret meetings and trying to provoke a reaction from her. Amber confronts Corinna about Bruce's infidelity and their son's true parentage, leading to a heated argument. Bruce intervenes and violently attacks Amber, but eventually stops when Corinna reveals she is in labor. Amber lies senseless on the floor after being attacked by Bruce, and then spends several days in her bedroom, feeling desolate and indifferent to everything around her. Amber arrives at an obscure lodging in Westminster and offers Lord Arlington valuable information in exchange for five thousand pounds, but he is skeptical and tries to negotiate. Amber warns him of a plot to murder him and they reach a tense agreement. Amber sees Almsbury at the palace and desperately asks him for news about Bruce, but he avoids her and refuses to help. Amber desperately waits in her coach to see Lord Carlton, but when she finally speaks to him, he no longer recognizes her and they part ways.

title: Forever Amber
author: Kathleen Winsor
text: She leans out and waves at the closed empty windows, still laughing.
